ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: ONLY TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOUR SERIOUS ABOUT ARABIC!! This isn't just for kicks and giggles or just to fulfill the language requirement. If you just need a language to take study some other romance language (I hear the French program is amazing). The first couple weeks will weed out the non-serious students.

Arabic is an absolutely essential language to know. I have the full intention of taking it for all 8 semesters. Is it a phenomenal department, no. It is a luck of the draw with teachers. My arabic has improved immensely and I am happy, not thrilled, with this semester.Also, the grades are really easy so long as you are good at memorization (and there isn't even that much memorization)

This is definitely a course to take only if you are serious about learning Arabic; otherwise, it will just seem like a drag. The first few weeks are quite work-intensive; you will find yourself doing 20-30 pages a night. However, this load decreases by a lot once those weeks have passed, and the workload is totally manageable from then on. Make sure you get a good professor-- ask people who have taken the course to give their recommendations. Trust me, it will make a huge impact.

I would only recommend Arabic at Yale to someone who is determined and prepared to study hard to keep up. If you have a genuine interest in Arabic then it will be rewarding, but if you're just looking to fulfill a language requirement go take Indonesian or something.
